event: treated with hepatic puncture and drainage
serum glutamic oxalacetic transaminase level of 67 U/L
blood urea nitrogen level of 10.8 mmol/L
drainage catheter yield of 150 mL of fulvous fluid
submitted to the microbiology laboratory for analysis
abdominal and pelvic computed tomography scan
irregular, slightly low-density lesion in the right posterior hepatic lobe
liquid density shadow and high-density drainage tube shadow
round-like low-density lesion of about 0.8 cm in diameter
appendix thickened to about 20 mm in diameter
structure of the ascending colon near the ileocecal region became disorganised
multiple gas accumulation and dilation in the bowel
taken to the operating room for urgent exploratory laparotomy
fulvous purulent exudate and necrotic tissue
partial postnecrotic defect in the peritoneum
massive epiploon adhesion in the right upper abdomen
partial resection of the ascending colon
drainage of hepatic, abdominal and extraperitoneal abscesses
transferred to the intensive care unit
empirically started on intravenous tigecycline and piperacillin/tazobactam
blood samples were taken for aerobic and anaerobic cultures
anaerobic blood culture vials were reported to be positive
Gram stain revealed short Gram-positive bacillus without spores
positive culture broth was inoculated onto blood agar base medium
anaerobically incubated for three more days
colony from the agar plate was identified as E. lenta
antimicrobial susceptibility testing of E. lenta was not performed
cultures of the drainage fluid were obtained
isolation of organism as Escherichia coli
fever, leukocytosis, PCT level and CRP level promptly improved
administered ertapenem and teicoplanin for another 14 days
debridement, dressing change and symptomatic supportive treatment
repeated blood cultures after the introduction of antibiotics were negative
repeat CT revealed that the size of the hepatic abscess and the amount of ascites decreased
follow-up with a six-week course of intravenous ertapenem
